BIOS329
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Programmes is due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1. This Yr3 module will therefore be delivered from September 2026.

Maximum of 40 students due to limited availability of human cadaveric specimens in the HARC.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of head and neck, building upon principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and 2. Successful completion of the earlier cadaveric anatomy modules on the programme is pre-requisite. The module also prepares learners for future practical modules such as the dissection module in Semester 2.

This module covers the anatomy of the main structures, including the brain and its integration with the spinal cord as well as, for example, the musculature, vasculature, and osteology of the head and neck.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• Develop in students, the knowledge and understanding of the topographical, structural and functional anatomy of the human head and neck region, including the brain and its association with the spinal cord.

• To encourage students to develop skills for interpreting medical imaging as it applies to the gross anatomy of the head and neck regions as well as the central nervous system.

• To broaden awareness of the anatomy underpinning key functions such as memory, communication (facial expression & auditory), mastication, vision, co-ordinated movement of the head and neck.

• To encourage critical understanding to solve problems in anatomy, ranging from clinical scenarios, advances of anatomical knowledge, and the integration of structure and function.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 3 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric specimens in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC). This module will consist of a series of weekly lectures and practicals (in HARC) where topics will be reinforced against the lecture material. There will also be access to formative assessments weekly such as online quizzes and questions, as well as self-assessment questions during practical sessions.

The head and neck is considered one of the most complex regions of the human body, containing systems critical to basic functions like feeding and breathing as well as more advanced functions such as communication and cognitive reasoning. Knowledge and understanding of these systems are paramount to many branches of science from psychology and linguistics through to neuroscience as well as careers like radiology and surgery, and emerging disciplines such as robotic augmentation. This module covers the anatomy of the main structures, including the brain and its integration with the spinal cord as well as, for example, the musculature, vasculature, and osteology of the head and neck. Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module covers the anatomy of the head and neck, which includes the brain and by extension spinal cord. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills learnt from previous modules of the degree.

Each week will centre around a theme -

Themes include:
• Musculature, glands, and osteology, including joints, sutures as well as foramina of the skull and vertebrae
• Blood supply of the head, neck and central nervous system
• Brain and cranial nerves, including the special senses
• Ascending and descending spinal cord pathways
• Infratemporal region as well as the posterior and anterior triangles of the neck
• Mouth, pharynx and larynx
• Meninges and cerebrospinal fluid
• Orbit, nose and sinuses

Within each of these, learning activities will consist of lectures on the theory behind each theme which will include but not limited to, the general gross anatomy, common human variations and applications in clinical, evolutionary and morphological scenarios . These are then reinforced in a practical setting using anatomical models, medical imaging, human prosections and online anatomical educational digital products such as anatomical videos and virtual dissection.

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will take the form of a blended approach that integrates lectures with hands-on practical sessions designed to reinforce key attributes. A typical week will include 3 one-hour lectures coupled with a 3-hour hands-on practical session in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Lecture - this refers to timetabled lectures that deliver core content and offer the opportunity for group discussion.

HARC practical - this refers to timetabled sessions in the HARC. These sessions will be structured to complement and reinforce the content delivered via lectures and provide opportunities for smaller group and 1-to -1 discussion, helping students clarify and synthesise key concepts.

Online content - this refers to asynchronous responsive mode delivery of on-line videos. These will be created with reference to formative assessment and informal feedback from students, helping them consolidate and clarify those aspects they find most challenging.

Self-directed Learning – this encompasses background reading, research and preparation for timetabled sessions as well as revision for summative assessments.

The implementation and combinations of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, including:

Inclusivity and Accessibility: whilst delivered linearly, the module is structured such that students can subsequently navigate content in different ways, finding the best approach for their needs. Lectures will be recorded and lecture notes as well as practical session handbooks will be posted online in pdf format, and used by most digital readers. The module will also recognise, and use examples that represent, the full breadth of human anatomical diversity.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances. Essay assessment submissions are expected to include research papers, referenced accordingly.

Active learning: The integration of lecture content with practical work actively engages students with the integration of kinaesthetic learning and of theoretical learning, framed by autodidactic and didactic modes of assimilating the core information and skills. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts as part of assessment is also inherently active.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion both in HARC practical sessions as well as the lecture theatre. Practical sessions involve collaborative group-work. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work and analyses, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through access to advanced digital resources such as 3D atlases as well as the embedding of diagnostic imaging into teaching, learning and assessments.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed via two assessments:

Cycle 1 (Week 6) – Synoptic essay exploring the structure and function covered in Weeks 1-5, including the students own background reading. It is worth 40% of the module. Feedback will be provided in the form of written comments and the marking rubric. Standard UoL penalties apply for later submission. Essays are marked anonymously. Maps to LO1, LO2 and S1, S2 and S3.

Cycle 2 (during assessment period). Practical assessment based on models, cadaveric specimens, and medical images. Students must identify structures and provide short answers to questions on function, structural and spatial relationships, integration with other attributes and functions, imaging and common aetiologies. Answer sheets are marked anonymously. Practical assessments are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Weighting is 60%. Maps to LO1, LO2, LO3 and S1, S2 and S3.

Practical assessments are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The written assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessment will be built into lectures (interactive online quiz questions etc) as well as practice spotter formative assessments that have traditionally been run by the Student Anatomical Society of the University of Liverpool.

Assessments are compensable.

Reassessment will take a similar format but with different topics or material. Practical reassessment is an oral exam and therefore not anonymous. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Appraise the structural and topographical complexity of the main anatomical attributes of the head and neck region.
 LO2 Integrate knowledge of spatial relationships and interconnectivity to explain the anatomical bases to important functions and structural interdependencies.
 LO3 Evaluate structure and function in the head and neck region using common diagnostic imaging modalities such as x-rays, CT and MRI scans.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Communicate scientific knowledge confidently to a specified audience using appropriate terminology.
 S2 Show awareness of ethical and legal constraints of working with cadaveric material.
 S3 Thinking critically and enhanced problem solving.

BIOS329
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Programmes is due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1. This Yr3 module will therefore be delivered from September 2026.

Maximum of 40 students due to limited availability of human cadaveric specimens in the HARC.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of head and neck, building upon principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and 2. Successful completion of the earlier cadaveric anatomy modules on the programme is pre-requisite. The module also prepares learners for future practical modules such as the dissection module in Semester 2.

This module covers the anatomy of the main structures, including the brain and its integration with the spinal cord as well as, for example, the musculature, vasculature, and osteology of the head and neck.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• Develop in students, the knowledge and understanding of the topographical, structural and functional anatomy of the human head and neck region, including the brain and its association with the spinal cord.

• To encourage students to develop skills for interpreting medical imaging as it applies to the gross anatomy of the head and neck regions as well as the central nervous system.

• To broaden awareness of the anatomy underpinning key functions such as memory, communication (facial expression & auditory), mastication, vision, co-ordinated movement of the head and neck.

• To encourage critical understanding to solve problems in anatomy, ranging from clinical scenarios, advances of anatomical knowledge, and the integration of structure and function.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 3 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric specimens in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC). This module will consist of a series of weekly lectures and practicals (in HARC) where topics will be reinforced against the lecture material. There will also be access to formative assessments weekly such as online quizzes and questions, as well as self-assessment questions during practical sessions.

The head and neck is considered one of the most complex regions of the human body, containing systems critical to basic functions like feeding and breathing as well as more advanced functions such as communication and cognitive reasoning. Knowledge and understanding of these systems are paramount to many branches of science from psychology and linguistics through to neuroscience as well as careers like radiology and surgery, and emerging disciplines such as robotic augmentation. This module covers the anatomy of the main structures, including the brain and its integration with the spinal cord as well as, for example, the musculature, vasculature, and osteology of the head and neck. Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module covers the anatomy of the head and neck, which includes the brain and by extension spinal cord. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills learnt from previous modules of the degree.

Each week will centre around a theme -

Themes include:
• Musculature, glands, and osteology, including joints, sutures as well as foramina of the skull and vertebrae
• Blood supply of the head, neck and central nervous system
• Brain and cranial nerves, including the special senses
• Ascending and descending spinal cord pathways
• Infratemporal region as well as the posterior and anterior triangles of the neck
• Mouth, pharynx and larynx
• Meninges and cerebrospinal fluid
• Orbit, nose and sinuses

Within each of these, learning activities will consist of lectures on the theory behind each theme which will include but not limited to, the general gross anatomy, common human variations and applications in clinical, evolutionary and morphological scenarios . These are then reinforced in a practical setting using anatomical models, medical imaging, human prosections and online anatomical educational digital products such as anatomical videos and virtual dissection.

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will take the form of a blended approach that integrates lectures with hands-on practical sessions designed to reinforce key attributes. A typical week will include 3 one-hour lectures coupled with a 3-hour hands-on practical session in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Lecture - this refers to timetabled lectures that deliver core content and offer the opportunity for group discussion.

HARC practical - this refers to timetabled sessions in the HARC. These sessions will be structured to complement and reinforce the content delivered via lectures and provide opportunities for smaller group and 1-to -1 discussion, helping students clarify and synthesise key concepts.

Online content - this refers to asynchronous responsive mode delivery of on-line videos. These will be created with reference to formative assessment and informal feedback from students, helping them consolidate and clarify those aspects they find most challenging.

Self-directed Learning – this encompasses background reading, research and preparation for timetabled sessions as well as revision for summative assessments.

The implementation and combinations of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, including:

Inclusivity and Accessibility: whilst delivered linearly, the module is structured such that students can subsequently navigate content in different ways, finding the best approach for their needs. Lectures will be recorded and lecture notes as well as practical session handbooks will be posted online in pdf format, and used by most digital readers. The module will also recognise, and use examples that represent, the full breadth of human anatomical diversity.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances. Essay assessment submissions are expected to include research papers, referenced accordingly.

Active learning: The integration of lecture content with practical work actively engages students with the integration of kinaesthetic learning and of theoretical learning, framed by autodidactic and didactic modes of assimilating the core information and skills. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts as part of assessment is also inherently active.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion both in HARC practical sessions as well as the lecture theatre. Practical sessions involve collaborative group-work. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work and analyses, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through access to advanced digital resources such as 3D atlases as well as the embedding of diagnostic imaging into teaching, learning and assessments.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed via two assessments:

Cycle 1 (Week 6) – Synoptic essay exploring the structure and function covered in Weeks 1-5, including the students own background reading. It is worth 40% of the module. Feedback will be provided in the form of written comments and the marking rubric. Standard UoL penalties apply for later submission. Essays are marked anonymously. Maps to LO1, LO2 and S1, S2 and S3.

Cycle 2 (during assessment period). Practical assessment based on models, cadaveric specimens, and medical images. Students must identify structures and provide short answers to questions on function, structural and spatial relationships, integration with other attributes and functions, imaging and common aetiologies. Answer sheets are marked anonymously. Practical assessments are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Weighting is 60%. Maps to LO1, LO2, LO3 and S1, S2 and S3.

Practical assessments are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The written assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessment will be built into lectures (interactive online quiz questions etc) as well as practice spotter formative assessments that have traditionally been run by the Student Anatomical Society of the University of Liverpool.

Assessments are compensable.

Reassessment will take a similar format but with different topics or material. Practical reassessment is an oral exam and therefore not anonymous. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Appraise the structural and topographical complexity of the main anatomical attributes of the head and neck region.
 LO2 Integrate knowledge of spatial relationships and interconnectivity to explain the anatomical bases to important functions and structural interdependencies.
 LO3 Evaluate structure and function in the head and neck region using common diagnostic imaging modalities such as x-rays, CT and MRI scans.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Communicate scientific knowledge confidently to a specified audience using appropriate terminology.
 S2 Show awareness of ethical and legal constraints of working with cadaveric material.
 S3 Thinking critically and enhanced problem solving.

A typical week will include 3 one-hour lectures coupled with a 3-hour hands-on practical session in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Lecture - this refers to timetabled lectures that deliver core content and offer the opportunity for group discussion.

HARC practical - this refers to timetabled sessions in the HARC. These sessions will be structured to complement and reinforce the content delivered via lectures and provide opportunities for smaller group and 1-to -1 discussion, helping students clarify and synthesise key concepts.

Online content - this refers to asynchronous responsive mode delivery of on-line videos. These will be created with reference to formative assessment and informal feedback from students, helping them consolidate and clarify those aspects they find most challenging.

Self-directed Learning – this encompasses background reading, research and preparation for timetabled sessions as well as revision for summative assessments.

The implementation and combinations of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, including:

Inclusivity and Accessibility: whilst delivered linearly, the module is structured such that students can subsequently navigate content in different ways, finding the best approach for their needs. Lectures will be recorded and lecture notes as well as practical session handbooks will be posted online in pdf format, and used by most digital readers. The module will also recognise, and use examples that represent, the full breadth of human anatomical diversity.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances. Essay assessment submissions are expected to include research papers, referenced accordingly.

Active learning: The integration of lecture content with practical work actively engages students with the integration of kinaesthetic learning and of theoretical learning, framed by autodidactic and didactic modes of assimilating the core information and skills. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts as part of assessment is also inherently active.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion both in HARC practical sessions as well as the lecture theatre. Practical sessions involve collaborative group-work. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work and analyses, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through access to advanced digital resources such as 3D atlases as well as the embedding of diagnostic imaging into teaching, learning and assessments.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed via two assessments:

Cycle 1 (Week 6) – Synoptic essay exploring the structure and function covered in Weeks 1-5, including the students own background reading. It is worth 40% of the module. Feedback will be provided in the form of written comments and the marking rubric. Standard UoL penalties apply for later submission. Essays are marked anonymously. Maps to LO1, LO2 and S1, S2 and S3.

Cycle 2 (during assessment period). Practical assessment based on models, cadaveric specimens, and medical images. Students must identify structures and provide short answers to questions on function, structural and spatial relationships, integration with other attributes and functions, imaging and common aetiologies. Answer sheets are marked anonymously. Practical assessments are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Weighting is 60%. Maps to LO1, LO2, LO3 and S1, S2 and S3.

Practical assessments are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The written assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessment will be built into lectures (interactive online quiz questions etc) as well as practice spotter formative assessments that have traditionally been run by the Student Anatomical Society of the University of Liverpool.

Assessments are compensable.

Reassessment will take a similar format but with different topics or material. Practical reassessment is an oral exam and therefore not anonymous. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS329
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Programmes is due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1. This Yr3 module will therefore be delivered from September 2026.

Maximum of 40 students due to limited availability of human cadaveric specimens in the HARC.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of head and neck, building upon principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and 2. Successful completion of the earlier cadaveric anatomy modules on the programme is pre-requisite. The module also prepares learners for future practical modules such as the dissection module in Semester 2.

This module covers the anatomy of the main structures, including the brain and its integration with the spinal cord as well as, for example, the musculature, vasculature, and osteology of the head and neck.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

• Develop in students, the knowledge and understanding of the topographical, structural and functional anatomy of the human head and neck region, including the brain and its association with the spinal cord.

• To encourage students to develop skills for interpreting medical imaging as it applies to the gross anatomy of the head and neck regions as well as the central nervous system.

• To broaden awareness of the anatomy underpinning key functions such as memory, communication (facial expression & auditory), mastication, vision, co-ordinated movement of the head and neck.

• To encourage critical understanding to solve problems in anatomy, ranging from clinical scenarios, advances of anatomical knowledge, and the integration of structure and function.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 3 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric specimens in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC). This module will consist of a series of weekly lectures and practicals (in HARC) where topics will be reinforced against the lecture material. There will also be access to formative assessments weekly such as online quizzes and questions, as well as self-assessment questions during practical sessions.

The head and neck is considered one of the most complex regions of the human body, containing systems critical to basic functions like feeding and breathing as well as more advanced functions such as communication and cognitive reasoning. Knowledge and understanding of these systems are paramount to many branches of science from psychology and linguistics through to neuroscience as well as careers like radiology and surgery, and emerging disciplines such as robotic augmentation. This module covers the anatomy of the main structures, including the brain and its integration with the spinal cord as well as, for example, the musculature, vasculature, and osteology of the head and neck. Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module covers the anatomy of the head and neck, which includes the brain and by extension spinal cord. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills learnt from previous modules of the degree.

Each week will centre around a theme -

Themes include:
• Musculature, glands, and osteology, including joints, sutures as well as foramina of the skull and vertebrae
• Blood supply of the head, neck and central nervous system
• Brain and cranial nerves, including the special senses
• Ascending and descending spinal cord pathways
• Infratemporal region as well as the posterior and anterior triangles of the neck
• Mouth, pharynx and larynx
• Meninges and cerebrospinal fluid
• Orbit, nose and sinuses

Within each of these, learning activities will consist of lectures on the theory behind each theme which will include but not limited to, the general gross anatomy, common human variations and applications in clinical, evolutionary and morphological scenarios . These are then reinforced in a practical setting using anatomical models, medical imaging, human prosections and online anatomical educational digital products such as anatomical videos and virtual dissection.

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will take the form of a blended approach that integrates lectures with hands-on practical sessions designed to reinforce key attributes. A typical week will include 3 one-hour lectures coupled with a 3-hour hands-on practical session in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Lecture - this refers to timetabled lectures that deliver core content and offer the opportunity for group discussion.

HARC practical - this refers to timetabled sessions in the HARC. These sessions will be structured to complement and reinforce the content delivered via lectures and provide opportunities for smaller group and 1-to -1 discussion, helping students clarify and synthesise key concepts.

Online content - this refers to asynchronous responsive mode delivery of on-line videos. These will be created with reference to formative assessment and informal feedback from students, helping them consolidate and clarify those aspects they find most challenging.

Self-directed Learning – this encompasses background reading, research and preparation for timetabled sessions as well as revision for summative assessments.

The implementation and combinations of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, including:

Inclusivity and Accessibility: whilst delivered linearly, the module is structured such that students can subsequently navigate content in different ways, finding the best approach for their needs. Lectures will be recorded and lecture notes as well as practical session handbooks will be posted online in pdf format, and used by most digital readers. The module will also recognise, and use examples that represent, the full breadth of human anatomical diversity.

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances. Essay assessment submissions are expected to include research papers, referenced accordingly.

Active learning: The integration of lecture content with practical work actively engages students with the integration of kinaesthetic learning and of theoretical learning, framed by autodidactic and didactic modes of assimilating the core information and skills. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts as part of assessment is also inherently active.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion both in HARC practical sessions as well as the lecture theatre. Practical sessions involve collaborative group-work. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work and analyses, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through access to advanced digital resources such as 3D atlases as well as the embedding of diagnostic imaging into teaching, learning and assessments.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed via two assessments:

Cycle 1 (Week 6) – Synoptic essay exploring the structure and function covered in Weeks 1-5, including the students own background reading. It is worth 40% of the module. Feedback will be provided in the form of written comments and the marking rubric. Standard UoL penalties apply for later submission. Essays are marked anonymously. Maps to LO1, LO2 and S1, S2 and S3.

Cycle 2 (during assessment period). Practical assessment based on models, cadaveric specimens, and medical images. Students must identify structures and provide short answers to questions on function, structural and spatial relationships, integration with other attributes and functions, imaging and common aetiologies. Answer sheets are marked anonymously. Practical assessments are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Weighting is 60%. Maps to LO1, LO2, LO3 and S1, S2 and S3.

Practical assessments are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The written assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessment will be built into lectures (interactive online quiz questions etc) as well as practice spotter formative assessments that have traditionally been run by the Student Anatomical Society of the University of Liverpool.

Assessments are compensable.

Reassessment will take a similar format but with different topics or material. Practical reassessment is an oral exam and therefore not anonymous. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
